questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of “jerky movements all over the body” that lasted for two minutes. The patient lost consciousness after the episode. The patient’s parent states that the patient has been having recent gait abnormalities and headaches for the past month. For the last few days, the headaches are worse in the morning and are relieved after bouts of nonbloody, nonbilious emesis. Past medical history is significant for Hashimoto thyroiditis, for which the patient takes levothyroxine. Family history is significant for systemic erythematosus lupus in the patient’s mother. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral papilledema and gait ataxia. The patient appears confused and has a laceration on the left side of her tongue. Which of the following investigations is most likely to reveal the cause of her episode?
questions.solution:
This patient, who had jerky movements accompanied by loss of consciousness, tongue bite and postictal confusion, most likely had an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (progressive headache, vomiting, papilledema) and cerebellar involvement (gait instability and ataxia) are highly suggestive of a cerebellar lesion obstructing ventricular flow. The patient requires urgent neuroimaging (e.g. MRI) for diagnosis.  

Seizures are mostly a symptom of ongoing structural, metabolic or systemic disorders, many of which are reversible. The mnemonic “VITAMINS” is helpful in remembering the possible causes.        

 

Option Analysis

❌ Electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is usually deferred immediately after a seizure because the results may be confounded by acute postictal changes. Moreover, EEG is of little diagnostic utility in this patient who has a high suspicion for a structural intracranial abnormality.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture (LP) is unlikely to be helpful and may be misleading, as seizure activity itself can lead to transient cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis. If necessary, LP should only be performed after ruling out a space-occupying lesion by appropriate neuroimaging studies, in order to avoid brain herniation.  
✅ MRI head:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum antinuclear antibody (ANA) screening:
Incorrect: Serum ANA is a screening test of choice for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although SLE can cause convulsions, this condition is usually associated with constitutional symptoms (like fatigue, fever, myalgia and weight loss) and classical malar rash, none of which are not seen in this patient.  
❌ Thyroid function tests:
Incorrect: Though Hashimoto thyroiditis can rarely cause encephalopathy, it usually presents with a stroke-like pattern of focal neurologic deficits and altered mentation. This patient with papilledema and headache that is relieved by vomiting instead has a high suspicion for a structural intracranial process.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine health evaluation. While sitting in the waiting room, the patient experiences an episode of crying during which she falls to the ground and starts rolling side-to-side. The patient’s eyes are closed shut and could not be opened by a nurse. The episode lasts for about 3 minutes, after which the patient is able to stand up and sit in a chair. The patient has experienced similar episodes several times in front of family members before. The patient has suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder after a sexual assault several years ago; the condition is now being managed with sertraline. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is alert and oriented. Oral examination reveals no tongue lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings of jactitation (rolling from side to side), forced closure of eyes, vocalization (crying) and rapid reorientation, together with the history of sexual assault, makes the diagnosis of Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES) most likely in this case.

PNES is defined as sudden disruption of motor, sensory, autonomic or cognitive function that is of psychologic origin (instead of excessive synchronous neuronal activity seen in seizures). It is most common in the third decade of life and has female predominance. Risk factors include learning disabilities, or a history of physical or psychosocial trauma (unwanted pregnancy, physical, verbal or sexual abuse, or assault). It typically lasts longer than 2 minutes and presents with inconsistent findings (e.g., variable motor activity, pelvic thrusting, and forced closure of eyes). According to DSM-V criteria, the diagnosis does not require a provider to judge whether the episode was intentionally produced, as this aspect of the presentation may not be reliably discerned, and such a judgement would not change management, which consists of psychological evaluation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS):
Incorrect: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizure (PNES) is commonly misdiagnosed as GTCS because of generalized motor symptoms. However, GTCS is characterized by loss of consciousness, diffuse, bilateral muscle stiffening and rhythmic jerking, and postictal confusion. Eyes are usually open during GTCS, and it is typically associated with frothing at the mouth, tongue biting, and incontinence.  
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Sertraline does not precipitate seizures or PNES. Common side effects include flu-like symptoms, GI distress, and sexual dysfunction.  
❌ Factitious disorder:
Incorrect: Factitious disorder involves voluntary and intentional production of symptoms to achieve a primary internal gain (medical attention, sympathy, or, sometimes, relief from emotional conflict). These patients commonly falsify somatic symptoms or commonly known disorders (like hyperthyroidism).  
✅ Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizure (PNES):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Malingering:
Incorrect: Malingering involves conscious and motivational faking of symptoms to attain a specific external gain (avoid work, obtain compensation). Even if the patient feigned the symptoms to get the doctor’s attention, PNES is still a more specific diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents due to inattentive behavior. The parents say that the patient’s teacher is concerned that the patient does not pay attention in class and has periods where she does not respond to her name. The patient was previously doing well in school, but her grades have declined over the past few months. The parents have also noticed the patient staring into space for 10-20 seconds, multiple times throughout the day. There is no history of falls or syncope associated with the episodes. The patient’s uncle has a history of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities, and the child appears playful and active. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Absence seizure (also called petit mal) is a type of generalized seizure (i.e. affecting both the cerebral hemispheres at onset), and it is one of the most common forms of pediatric epilepsy. The seizure manifests in school-aged children and adolescents as a brief staring spell causing transient loss of consciousness without loss of body tone. It usually lasts about 10 seconds and cannot be interrupted by verbal/tactile stimuli (as opposed to staring spells that occur out of boredom or lack of focus). There is no postictal confusion or sedation, but the patient is unable to recall the event. Automatisms (lip smacking, rapid blinking) are observed sometimes, especially when the episode lasts for more than 10 seconds.  

Absence seizures can easily be provoked by hyperventilation, and electroencephalogram (EEG) exhibits classical 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges. The first line agent for the treatment of absence seizures is ethosuximide, which inhibits T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons. Valproic acid can be used if ethosuximide is ineffective or not tolerated. Absence seizures are typically benign and resolve before puberty.  



Option Analysis

❌ Selective mutism:
Incorrect: Selective mutism is an uncommon disorder in which the child fails to communicate in a specific social place (like school) but speaks normally in other settings (like home). This child’s abnormal behavior is not limited to a specific setting.  
❌ Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with absence seizure can easily be misdiagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Although it may present similarly with “inattention,” the staring spells observed in ADHD are actually due to lack of focus and can be interrupted by verbal or tactile stimulus. Moreover, the condition is usually accompanied by poor impulse control.  
❌ Autism spectrum disorder:
Incorrect: Although patients with autism spectrum disorder exhibit impaired social interactions, the condition is characterized by repetitive patterns of behavior or interests, and it usually presents by age 2. Staring spells are atypical.  
✅ Generalized seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Focal seizure:
Incorrect: Focal seizures (previously called partial seizures) affect only one hemisphere of the brain. Although patients with a focal temporal lobe seizure can present with blank staring, the episode usually lasts >30 seconds. Temporal lobe seizures are also typically accompanied by aura (olfactory hallucination or rising epigastric sensation), though this particular symptom may be difficult to elucidate in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abnormal behavior. He was having lunch with his family when he noted a pungent smell of burning rubber followed by uncontrollable lip smacking. The patient became unresponsive for a minute after which his whole body started shaking, and he fell to the ground. The patient experienced urinary incontinence during the episode. Past medical history is significant for seizures in childhood precipitated by high fevers. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. The patient appears confused and is unable to recall what happened. Physical examination shows bite marks on the tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Focal seizures are defined as seizures originating in a single cerebral hemisphere. These are usually preceded by aura, depending on the area involved in the abnormal discharges, and are sub-divided into simple or complex based on whether consciousness is intact or lost. This patient most likely had a complex focal seizure arising from the temporal lobe, based on localization findings of olfactory hallucinations (smelling burning rubber) followed by automatisms (lip smacking) and loss of consciousness. Moreover, it secondarily generalized into tonic-clonic seizure, as evidenced by generalized shaking and tongue biting. Seizures arising from the temporal lobe are usually due to mesial temporal sclerosis, which is associated with childhood febrile seizures.  



Option Analysis

❌ Simple focal seizure:
Incorrect: Focal seizure with retained awareness (also called simple focal seizure) is a type of focal seizure in which the patient returns immediately to their pre-event baseline without losing consciousness. This patient has lost consciousness and is having postictal confusion.  
✅ Focal seizure with secondary generalization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stroke:
Incorrect: Stroke is very uncommon in this age group. When present, it is usually associated with genetic, cardiac, vascular or hematologic abnormalities, or CNS infections. It usually manifests as hemiparesis, aphasia, headache and/or vomiting. It is unlikely in this patient with olfactory aura and motor automatisms.  
❌ Febrile seizure:
Incorrect: A febrile seizure usually occurs between the age of 6 months to 6 years. It is associated with high fevers. Although this patient has a history of febrile seizures, the current body temperature is normal.  
❌ Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:
Incorrect: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is a type of familial generalized epilepsy disorder that manifests as involuntary jerking movements involving both the extremities in adolescents. However, consciousness is preserved during and after the episode, with symptoms usually occurring in the morning.

questions.text: Q1. A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner after finding the patient unconscious in her room in soiled clothes this afternoon. The partner states the patient has been under significant stress lately due to upcoming exams. Past medical history is significant for migraine, for which the patient takes topiramate. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears tired and confused and is unable to recall what happened. Physical examination shows a bite mark on the tongue. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s loss of consciousness?
questions.solution:
The examination findings in this patient, together with loss of consciousness and postictal state, are consistent with a diagnosis of generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS). It is the most common type of generalized seizures, and it manifests as a generalized stiffness of muscles (tonic phase) that is followed by jerking and twitching (clonic phase). The patient loses consciousness during the episode and remains in deep sleep for a few minutes, followed by postictal confusion. The episode can be overlooked if the patient is alone. However, it is usually accompanied by tongue bite, urinary and/or fecal incontinence and amnesia of the event, all of which are seen in this patient. Certain triggers or precipitants tend to lower seizure threshold. These include, but are not limited to, strong emotions, flashing lights, fever, stress and lack of sleep (as in this patient).  

Option Analysis

❌ Vasovagal syncope:
Incorrect: Although emotional or orthostatic stress can be an inciting event for a vasovagal syncope in young individuals, it is not followed by postictal confusion, and the patient usually recalls a prodrome of pallor, dizziness, nausea or diaphoresis.  
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Medications that can induce or precipitate seizure activity in susceptible individuals include bupropion, isoniazid, lithium, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants, and several others. Topiramate is an anticonvulsant and can cause sedation, weight loss or renal calculi. It does not, however, precipitate seizures.  
❌ Migraine attack:
Incorrect: Migraine is an episodic disorder causing severe headache that is generally associated with nausea and/or light and sound sensitivity. Although it is also exacerbated by stress and sleep disturbance, it does not cause or precipitate seizure activity.  
❌ Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizure (PNES):
Incorrect: PNES is derived from psychological underpinnings and tends to occur in front of witnesses. Its duration is usually longer than 2 minutes and vocalization is observed during the episode. It is unlikely in this patient who was found alone with tongue bite, incontinence and postictal drowsiness and confusion.  
✅ Generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS):
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by a parent because of weakness in the left arm for about an hour. The patient was completing a school assignment when she experienced a brief episode of sudden, involuntary stiffening in the left arm, after which she lost consciousness for a few minutes. The parent, who witnessed the episode, states that the patient was moving her legs as if riding a bicycle. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears drowsy and confused. Physical examination shows motor strength is 4/5 in the left upper extremity. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Focal seizures are defined as seizures originating from a single cerebral hemisphere, which can be subdivided into simple focal seizures (also called focal seizures with retained awareness) and complex focal seizures (also called focal seizures with impaired awareness).  

In complex focal seizures, the patient becomes unresponsive (blank staring) and often exhibits automatisms (e.g., lip smacking, hand fidgeting, eye blinking) along with localizing symptoms, followed by a brief loss of consciousness.  

This patient most likely had a complex focal seizure arising from the frontal lobe. Abnormal discharges in this area are sometimes preceded by an aura of fear and anxiety followed by hypermotor tonic episodes (stiffening of arm), automatisms like leg bicycling, pelvic thrusting (sexual automatism) and/or vocalization during the episode. As the patient regains consciousness, a brief period of paralysis can be observed in the affected area -- a phenomenon called Todd’s paralysis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Simple focal seizure:
Incorrect: A simple focal seizure is a type of seizure in which the patient returns immediately to their pre-event baseline without losing consciousness. The symptoms depend on the area of the brain that is involved, ranging from motor (frontal lobe), auditory/olfactory (temporal lobe), visual (occipital lobe) or sensory (parietal lobe).  
✅ Complex focal seizure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ischemic stroke:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke would be very unlikely in this age group. When present, it is usually associated with genetic, cardiac, vascular or hematologic abnormalities, or CNS infections. It typically manifests as hemiparesis, aphasia, headache and/or vomiting. This patient’s weakness in the left upper extremity is most likely due to Todd’s paralysis (brief period of paralysis following a seizure).  
❌ Generalized tonic-clonic seizure:
Incorrect: Generalized tonic-clonic seizure is characterized by loss of consciousness with diffuse, bilateral muscle stiffening, accompanied by rhythmic jerking. It is usually associated with tongue biting, incontinence, and postictal confusion.  
❌ Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:
Incorrect: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is a type of familial generalized epilepsy disorder that manifests as involuntary jerking movements involving the bilateral extremities in adolescents. Consciousness is preserved during and after the episode, with symptoms usually occurring in the morning.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because her body started shaking violently 10 minutes ago at a nearby bus stop. She was waiting for a bus with her partner when she suddenly fell down and started having stiffening and jerking movements involving all four extremities. Past medical history is significant for epilepsy, for which the patient takes lamotrigine. The partner notes the patient recently started taking a combined oral contraceptive pill. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 112/min and regular, respirations are 22/min and blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg. The patient is unable to respond to vocal commands. Physical examination shows ongoing symmetric rhythmic jerking of the limbs. After appropriate supportive treatment, the patient is given a drug intramuscularly, after which the jerking subsides. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug administered?

choices.text: Sodium channel blocker at excitatory neuron
Increase in the frequency of chloride channel opening

questions.solution:
Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) is a medical emergency and is defined as continuous seizure activity for ≥5 minutes or ≥2 discrete seizures between which there is incomplete recovery of consciousness. This patient recently started taking combined oral contraceptive pills, which are known to increase the metabolism and clearance of lamotrigine; this metabolic alteration results in decreased serum levels of the antiepileptic medication, with subsequent increased risk of seizure recurrence.  

 The general management of GCSE involves the following:  

  1.  Assessment and supportive treatment: This step includes a rapid neurological examination, in addition to supportive therapy in order to maintain their airway, breathing, and circulation.  
  2.  Initial pharmacologic therapy with a benzodiazepine: Benzodiazepines are potent GABAA receptor analogues which facilitate the uptake of chloride ions by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening. This influx results in hyperpolarization of the neuron, aborting excess neuronal activity. In cases where intravenous (IV) access is available, IV lorazepam or diazepam is used. In cases where IV access is unavailable, intramuscular midazolam is typically used, as shown here.  
  3.  Urgent therapy with a nonbenzodiazepine anti-epileptic drug (e.g. fosphenytoin): In addition to a benzodiazepine, a nonbenzodiazepine is typically given IV for long-term control, in order to prevent seizure recurrence.  

Option Analysis

❌ Thalamic T-type Ca+2 channel blocker:
Incorrect: Ethosuximide blocks T-type Ca+2 channels found in the thalamus. It is used as a first-line agent for the management of absence seizure, which is a type of generalized seizure usually observed in children that presents with brief blank staring spells multiple times a day.  
❌ Synaptic vesicle protein (SV2A) receptor blocker:
Incorrect: Levetiracetam binds to synaptic vesicle protein (SV2A) to alter its fusion with the membrane, thereby inhibiting the release of neurotransmitters. It is widely used in the management of idiopathic generalized epilepsy, but it is not indicated for status epilepticus.  
❌ Inhibition of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) breakdown:
Incorrect: Valproate and vigabatrin are antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) known to inhibit the breakdown of GABA by blocking GABA transaminase, an enzyme present in inhibitory neurons. Valproate also inhibits Na+ channels at excitatory neurons. These drugs are not effective in emergency management of status epilepticus.  
❌ Sodium channel blocker at excitatory neuron:
Incorrect: Phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, topiramate and valproate inhibit excessive neuronal discharges that can precipitate a seizure by blocking voltage-gated Na+ channel on the membrane of presynaptic excitatory neurons. Phenytoin or valproate can be tried if benzodiazepine therapy fails, but none of these medications should be used as a first-line agent in status epilepticus.  
✅ Increase in the frequency of chloride channel opening:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parent due to concern that the patient is struggling in school. The patient’s teacher has noticed that there are times when the patient seems distracted and does not respond to his name. The patient was born at term via a normal vaginal delivery, and he has reached all developmental milestones. An electroencephalogram shows generalized spike-wave discharges of 4 Hz with abrupt onset and termination. Further laboratory tests and imaging show no abnormalities. The clinician prescribes the most appropriate treatment for the patient’s condition. This medication works by which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Increasing the release of catecholamines into the synaptic cleft
Increasing the duration of Cl− channel opening

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old child is having episodes of staring into space and not responding when being called by his name, which is impacting his performance at school. He is most likely suffering from absence seizures, which is a type of generalized seizure.  

Childhood absence epilepsy is one of the most common forms of generalized epilepsy syndromes in the pediatric population. An absence seizure is characterized by episodes of sudden impairment of consciousness, without loss of body tone or postictal confusion. Ictal signs include staring, oral automatisms, and eye involvement; however, not all three signs must be present. Absence seizures can be provoked by hyperventilation and corresponds with typical 2.5-5 Hz spike-wave activity on EEG. The seizures are often subtle, and thus they can go unnoticed for prolonged periods or be confused with conditions such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The first-line treatment is ethosuximide, which works by blocking T-type Ca2+ channels in the thalamus.  



Option Analysis

❌ Increasing the release of catecholamines into the synaptic cleft:
Incorrect: Increasing the release of catecholamines in the synaptic cleft is the mechanism of methylphenidate, a medication used for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, not for the treatment of absence seizures.   
✅ Blocking T-type Ca2+ channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibiting high voltage-activated Ca2+ channels:
Incorrect: Inhibiting high voltage-activated Ca2+ channels is the mechanism of gabapentin, a GABA analog that is used mainly to treat peripheral neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia. It is not indicated in the treatment of absence seizures.  
❌ Inhibiting GABA breakdown:
Incorrect: Inhibiting GABA breakdown is the mechanism of vigabatrin, which is used for partial (focal) seizures. It is not indicated for the treatment of absence seizures.   
❌ Increasing the duration of Cl− channel opening:
Incorrect: Increasing the duration of Cl− channel opening is the mechanism of barbiturates. These medications can be used as a sedative agent for anxiety, seizures, insomnia, and induction of anesthesia. However, they are not commonly used, due to a high side effect profile. They are not indicated for the treatment of absence seizures.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She does not have a prior history of seizure disorder. Past medical history is significant for severe persistent asthma, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Five days ago, the patient was started on ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection. Her other medications include inhaled fluticasone/salmeterol combination, theophylline, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Her BMI is 37 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which medications is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has recently started on ciprofloxacin, likely developed theophylline toxicity and resultant seizure due to drug-drug interaction.  

Theophylline is an oral methylxanthine. It inhibits phosphodiesterase, converting cAMP into an inactive form called 5-AMP. Blocking this enzyme increases the cAMP level within the cell, causing smooth muscle relaxation in the bronchial airways. Blocking adenosine receptors throughout the body blocks adenosine typically increases smooth muscle contraction in the respiratory tract. This mechanism could explain some of its bronchodilator effects.  

Methylxanthines are metabolized by cytochrome p450. This medication is sometimes considered in patients with mild asthma or as an add-on long-term control medication in moderate to severe asthma after the failure of other medications. Its use in patients with COPD is controversial, with only a few studies showing improvement in functional impairment. However, theophylline is generally avoided because it has a narrow therapeutic index and is very easy to reach supratherapeutic levels. This could cause insomnia, nausea, and vomiting, but the most dangerous side effects include overstimulation of the central nervous and cardiovascular systems, leading to seizures and arrhythmias. Medications that inhibit these enzymes (e.g., fluoxetine or ciprofloxacin) should be avoided.

Option Analysis

❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. Its typical side effects include cough and angioedema. It is, however, not associated with the development of seizures.
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that inhibits NaCl reabsorption in the early distal convoluted tubule. Its significant side effects include hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, and hyperglycemia. It does not interact with ciprofloxacin and is unlikely to cause seizures.
✅ Theophylline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Salmeterol:
Incorrect: Salmeterol is a long-acting beta-agonist that relaxes bronchial smooth muscle by selective action on beta-2 receptors with little effect on heart rate. It acts locally in the lung. It does not interact with ciprofloxacin and is unlikely to cause seizures.
❌ Fluticasone:
Incorrect: Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid associated with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. It does not interact with ciprofloxacin and is unlikely to cause seizures.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent for evaluation of staring spells. The parent tells the physician that he often stares and becomes unresponsive for several seconds at a time. Afterward, the child does not recall the event. The physician gives the patient a paper bag and asks him to blow in it quickly while having an EEG performed. After a few minutes of hyperventilation, the child stares at the wall appearing unresponsive for several seconds. During the episode, the EEG shows 3-hertz spike-and-wave discharges. The physician decides to start the patient on ethosuximide. Which of the following is the primary target of the medication most likely used to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This child presents clinical findings consistent with absence seizures confirmed via EEG testing showing 3-hertz spike-and-wave discharges. Ethosuximide is the first-line treatment of absence seizures.    

Ethosuximide is an anti-epileptic medication that inhibits voltage-gated calcium channels in presynaptic nerve terminals. Specifically, ethosuximide inhibits T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are thought to contribute to the pathophysiology of absence seizures directly. Inhibition of T-type calcium channels prevents excitatory neurotransmitters (i.e. glutamate) from being released, halting the propagation of the action potential and thus seizure activity.  

Other anti-epileptic medications that also work by inhibiting the voltage-gated calcium channels include gabapentin and levetiracetam.    



Option Analysis

✅ Voltage-gated calcium channels :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Voltage-gated sodium channels:
Incorrect: Blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels is the mechanism of action of multiple anti-epileptics including carbamazepine, phenytoin, and lamotrigine. Absence seizures are best treated with ethosuximide, which works via inhibition of T-type calcium channels. 
❌ GABA-A receptors:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates directly stimulate GABA-A receptors–not ethosuximide. 
❌ Potassium channels:
Incorrect: Ethosuximide does exert effects on potassium channels. Ezogabine is an anti-epileptic that works by opening neuronal potassium channels. 
❌ N-methyl-D-aspartic acid (NMDA) receptors:
Incorrect: Ethosuximide does not affect NMDA receptors. Felbamate anti-epileptic has NMDA receptor antagonist properties.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His past medical history is significant for nephrotic syndrome due to membranous glomerulopathy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bloodwork reveals a normal creatinine clearance. The physician decides to start the patient on phenytoin with one loading dose followed by a maintenance dose. Which of the following alterations should be made to the dosing given this patient’s underlying nephrotic syndrome?

choices.text: Lower loading dose and maintenance dose

questions.solution:
Volume of distribution refers to a theoretical volume that denotes how much space a medication (“drug”) occupies in the body. Small volumes of distribution (e.g., 3 liters) signify a medication that is mostly or exclusively found in plasma. Large volumes of distribution (e.g., 60 liters) signify a medication that is found throughout the body. Although each medication has a set volume of distribution, altered physiology can change this value. Diseases such as cirrhosis and nephrotic syndrome can increase the volume of distribution of medication, requiring a higher dose to achieve the same effect. In contrast, pathologic states such as severe dehydration can reduce the volume of distribution.  

Maintenance doses are affected by the underlying renal or hepatic function. With renal or hepatic impairment,  medications are not cleared as quickly, so lower doses are administered to achieve the same results. Impaired medication clearance is incredibly important in clinical practice, as certain medications can become toxic quickly if the dose is not reduced in patients with impaired clearance (e.g., morphine and renal clearance).  

Option Analysis

✅ Higher loading dose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lower loading dose:
Incorrect: Since the volume of distribution is elevated in nephrotic syndrome, a higher loading dose for medications is generally required.
❌ Higher maintenance dose:
Incorrect: Higher maintenance doses may be required in patients who previously had impaired kidney or liver function, with subsequent improvement. There is no indication that this patient requires higher maintenance doses.
❌ Lower maintenance dose:
Incorrect: Lower maintenance doses may be required in patients with impaired clearance (either via the kidney or liver). There is no indication that this patient has renal or hepatic impairment, so clearance should not be affected.
❌ Lower loading dose and maintenance dose:
Incorrect: A lower loading dose may be required in a patient with a smaller volume of distribution (e.g., severe dehydration). A lower maintenance dose may be required in patients with impaired renal or hepatic function.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department in status epilepticus. Per emergency medical services, the patient was wandering the streets aimlessly when a bystander saw him fall to the ground and shake uncontrollably. Past medical history is unknown. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals a disheveled male with uncontrolled tremors in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. The patient is given a medication that works by increasing the rate of chloride channel opening via agonism of the GABAA receptor. Which of the following medications was most likely used in the treatment of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with status epilepticus is administered a medication that increases the rate of chloride channel opening via allosteric modulation of the GABAA receptor. This description is most consistent with the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines. Of the medications listed, only lorazepam falls into this medication class.  

Both benzodiazepines and barbiturates act on the GABAA receptor and affect chloride-selective ion channels. These effects lead to neuronal hyperpolarization and decreased excitability. Therefore, these medications are excellent for acute seizure control.    

However, benzodiazepines and barbiturates differ in their specific mechanisms of action. Benzodiazepines facilitate GABAA activity by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening, whereas barbiturates work by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening.  

Ultimately, this mechanistic difference accounts for a “gating effect” with benzodiazepines, such that only a certain amount of GABA can be released upon medication binding. In contrast, with barbiturate use, the chloride channel is in an open state while the medication exerts its effects. As a result, barbiturates are associated with uninhibited GABA release, which can manifest as more profound sedative effects and increased toxicity in overdose when compared to benzodiazepines. 

Option Analysis

✅ Lorazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phenobarbital:
Incorrect: Phenobarbital, a barbiturate, can be used in the treatment of status epilepticus. However, the mechanism of action of barbiturates is slightly different than that of benzodiazepines. This class of medication works by binding to GABAA receptors and increasing the duration of chloride channel opening.
❌ Thiopental :
 Incorrect: Thiopental is a barbiturate that works by increasing the duration, not the frequency, of chloride channel opening.  
❌ Levetiracetam :
Incorrect: Levetiracetam is an anti-epileptic medication that has an unclear mechanism of action but is thought to modulate GABA and glutamate release as well as inhibit voltage-gated Ca2+  channels. 
❌ Phenytoin :
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic medication that works via sodium channel blockade. It does not act on the GABA receptors.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his neurologist for a routine follow-up. For the past six months, the patient occasionally smells “burnt rubber,” followed by a motionless stare where the patient becomes unresponsive. Non-contrast head CT performed at follow-up one month ago was within normal limits. The patient was diagnosed with medial temporal lobe epilepsy and prescribed carbamazepine. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with medial temporal lobe epilepsy–a focal seizure disorder originating from the medial temporal lobe. Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant frequently used in focal epilepsy treatment and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.    

Carbamazepine works by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels. Ultimately, this effect inhibits the generation of action potentials and release of excitatory neurotransmitters inhibiting seizure activity.    

Other anticonvulsants that also work via inhibiting the voltage-gated sodium channels include valproic acid, phenytoin, topiramate, and lamotrigine. Some of these medications exert additional effects that contribute to their anticonvulsant properties.  



Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ GABA-A receptor agonist :
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates are GABA analogs that directly stimulate GABA-A receptors. 
❌ Inhibition of GABA reuptake :
Incorrect: Tiagabine is an anticonvulsant that works via inhibiting GABA reuptake. Benzodiazepines do not inhibit GABA reuptake.
❌ Inhibition of GABA breakdown :
Incorrect: GABA transaminase is the enzyme responsible for breaking down GABA, which is inhibited by anticonvulsants like valproate and vigabatrin. 
❌  Inhibition of voltage-gated calcium channels:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine as an anticonvulsant inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels, not voltage-gated calcium channels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for routine follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with complex temporal lobe seizures associated with impaired consciousness one year ago. A brain MRI was performed at that time and was unrevealing. She has been taking carbamazepine since then but continues to have breakthrough seizures. The physician changes the patient to a medication that works by inhibiting the brain's breakdown of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA). Which of the following is the most likely medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a poorly controlled seizure disorder and is initiated on a medication that inhibits the breakdown of GABA. Of the choices listed, only vigabatrin is known to carry this mechanism of action.    

GABA serves as the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. When released in the nerve terminals, it binds to the GABA-A receptors in postsynaptic membranes, opening chloride channels, and allowing negatively charged chloride to enter the cell. This results in hyperpolarization of the postsynaptic membrane, thus inhibiting action potential generation. GABA is then taken up by adjacent neurons and broken down by the enzyme GABA transaminase.    

Certain anti-epileptic medications exert their effect by increasing the concentration of GABA in nerve terminals, which inhibits neuronal excitation and subsequent seizure activity.
   
  •  Tiagabine is a GABA reuptake inhibitor that blocks the channels responsible for GABA reuptake, thus increasing the concentration of GABA in the synaptic cleft.  
  •  Vigabatrin and valproic acid are two antiepileptics that inhibit GABA transaminase, thus enhancing the effects of inhibitory neurons.  


Option Analysis

✅ Vigabatrin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phenobarbital :
Incorrect: Phenobarbital binds to GABA-A receptors and inhibits action potential generation in the central nervous system. This medication does not inhibit the breakdown of GABA. 
❌ Phenytoin :
Incorrect: Phenytoin inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels and the propagation of action potentials in nerve terminals. It exerts no effect on the metabolism of GABA. 
❌ Gabapentin :
Incorrect: Gabapentin acts as a GABA analog that works by inhibiting voltage-gated calcium channels. It exerts no effect on GABA metabolism. 
❌ Lamotrigine :
Incorrect:  Lamotrigine inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels and glutamate release. It does not affect GABA metabolism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate the recurrent loss of consciousness. His partner tells the physician that he has suffered multiple episodes where he suddenly falls to the floor, shaking uncontrollably. These episodes last less than a minute, and the patient appears confused after that. Non-contrast head CT scan is within normal limits, and his labs do not reveal any abnormalities. He is diagnosed with generalized tonic-clonic seizures and initiated on lamotrigine. In addition to inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels, which other mechanism of action does this medication carry that helps to control seizures?

choices.text: Decrease glutamate release in the central nervous system
Increase glutamate release in the central nervous system
Directly bind to and stimulate the GABA-A receptor

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and was started on lamotrigine–an antiepileptic medication that works via two primary mechanisms: voltage-gated sodium channel blockade and inhibition of glutamate release.    

Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and is associated with an increased propensity for seizure development. When released in the synaptic cleft, glutamate opens ligand-gated ion channels and induces depolarization of the postsynaptic membrane inducing action potentials.  

Antiepileptic medications associated with decreased release of glutamate include lamotrigine and topiramate. These anticonvulsants inhibit voltage-gated sodium channels, while topiramate inhibits voltage-gated calcium channels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Decrease glutamate release in the central nervous system :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase glutamate release in the central nervous system :
Incorrect: Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter.  Increased glutamate release in the central nervous system is associated with a lower seizure threshold. Lamotrigine decreases the release of glutamate. 
❌ Inhibit the breakdown of GABA :
Incorrect: GABA is broken down by the enzyme GABA transaminase, which is inhibited by vigabatrin and valproic acid. Lamotrigine does not inhibit this enzyme. 
❌ Inhibit the reuptake of GABA :
Incorrect: Tiagabine is an antiepileptic drug that inhibits the reuptake of GABA. Lamotrigine does not inhibit GABA reuptake.
❌ Directly bind to and stimulate the GABA-A receptor:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates bind to the GABA-A receptor and stimulate it, not lamotrigine.

questions.text: A 73-year-old person comes to a neurology clinic to establish care after a recent hospitalization for stroke. The patient sustained acute right-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the left middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy due to presenting eight hours following symptom onset. Muscle strength significantly improved after physical therapy. However, the patient reports that they are now unable to differentiate between the fingers in their right hand, and they are now unable to write. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength is 4/5 on the right side. When asked to elevate the left hand, the patient elevates the right hand. The patient is unable to solve a simple mathematical problem. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with inability to recognize individual fingers (finger agnosia), left-right disorientation, and acalculia (inability to solve simple math); they most likely have Gerstmann syndrome. 

The angular gyrus refers to an area located in the inferior parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere that integrates visual, acoustic, and somatosensory information necessary for problem solving (in particular, speech and number processing). It is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of these arteries in the dominant hemisphere can result in Gerstmann Syndrome (as in this patient), or, in rare cases, the syndrome can result from a traumatic brain injury or a brain tumor in the same region. Clinical manifestations include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia (inability to write), and alexia (inability to read).  



Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.  
❌ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body). 
✅ Gerstmann syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden-onset dizziness, nausea, and weakness. The patient was gardening when he suddenly felt unsteady and noted the world was “spinning” around him. Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient is an active smoker with a 35-pack-year history. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 168/104 mmHg. The left pupil is slightly constricted when compared to the right with concomitant left-sided ptosis. Rotary and vertical nystagmus is present. There is impaired pinprick and temperature sensation on the left side of the face, right trunk, and right upper, and right lower extremities. Which of the following vascular territories is most likely affected given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vertigo, Horner syndrome of the left face, and impaired sensation of the left face and right body consistent with a stroke of the posterior circulation. More specifically, this patient's presentation is consistent with left lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome.

Lateral medullary syndrome results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or one of its medullary branches, such as the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). A stroke in this anatomic distribution results in damage to the the following structures with associated symptoms:

  •  Vestibular nuclei: nystagmus, nausea, vertigo 
  •  Nucleus ambiguus of CN IX and X: ipsilateral laryngeal and pharyngeal paralysis, loss of the gag reflex, dysarthria, dysphagia, and dysphonia 
  •  Spinothalamic tracts: contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the trunk and extremities 
  •  Spinal trigeminal nucleus and tract: ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face 
  •  Descending sympathetic tract: ipsilateral Horner syndrome
 


Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This area refers to the right lateral medulla, which becomes implicated in occlusions of the right vertebral artery or one of its medullary branches, such as the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). In right lateral medullary syndrome, patients present with ipsilateral cerebellar signs, ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the trunk and extremities.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Right medial medullary syndrome results in left-sided hemiparesis of the trunk and extremities, left-sided loss of proprioception, tactile sensation, and vibratory sensation, as well as right-sided flaccid paralysis of the tongue.
❌ C:
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome results in contralateral hemiparesis of the trunk and extremities, contralateral loss of proprioception, tactile sensation, and vibratory sensation, as well as ipsilateral flaccid paralysis of the tongue.
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found unresponsive at home. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension. The patient's last medication refill was almost two years ago. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 240/190 mm Hg. The patient has extensor posturing and pinpoint pupils. A CT scan of the head without contrast is shown below.  


Reproduced from Radiopedia  
Despite resuscitative measures, the patient dies several hours later. Damage to which of the following structures is most associated with the depressed level of consciousness observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a hypertensive hemorrhage in the posterior rostral pons, a portion of the brainstem that houses the reticular activating system (RAS).

The RAS is a network of neurons originating in the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain that is especially important in maintaining consciousness. The RAS sends fibers towards the cerebral cortex, ensuring wakefulness and the ability to recognize and react to stimuli. Lesions of the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain RAS reduce the level of arousal and consciousness, leading to lethargy, stupor, and coma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rostral ventral medulla  :
Incorrect: The rostral ventromedial medulla refers to a group of neurons located close to the midline of the medulla oblongata. This region transmits both descending inhibitory and excitatory fibers to dorsal horn spinal cord neurons, which are characterized by their response to nociceptive inputs.  
✅ Reticular activating system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Internal capsule:
Incorrect: Damage to the internal capsule presents with contralateral hemiparesis, dysarthria, and contralateral hemisensory loss. The internal capsule is often affected in patients with putaminal hemorrhages. This patient’s CT scan is suggestive of a pontine hemorrhage.  
❌ Posterior pituitary  :
Incorrect: The posterior pituitary releases oxytocin and vasopressin produced by the hypothalamus. These hormones do not play a role in maintaining consciousness.  
❌ Basal ganglia  :
Incorrect: The “basal ganglia” refers to a group of subcortical nuclei responsible for motor control, motor learning, executive and behavioral function, as well as emotional regulation. It is not involved in maintaining consciousness.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to new-onset right lower extremity weakness. The patient first noticed this weakness after he had difficulty standing up from his bed this morning. He reports a mild headache but has not had blurred vision, back pain, or history of trauma. Past medical history is significant for a recently diagnosed primary tumor of the frontal lobe and osteoarthritis. The patient takes acetaminophen for joint pain. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 200/96 mm Hg. Right lower extremity examination demonstrates 0/5 muscle strength, and deep tendon reflexes are 3+ with a positive Babinski sign. Sensation is decreased throughout the right foot and leg. Left lower extremity and bilateral upper extremity examinations are unremarkable. Further imaging confirms a brain herniation syndrome at the site marked with the arrow in the image below.
 

 Which of the following is a possible complication of the type of brain herniation indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
There are several types of brain herniation, including subfalcine, uncal, transtentorial (upward and downward), and tonsillar herniation–all occur in response to increased intracranial pressure. The type of herniation denoted in the figure above is described as subfalcine/cingulate herniation.   

With subfalcine herniation, the innermost part of the frontal lobe, called the cingulate gyrus, herniates below the free edge of the falx cerebri toward the contralateral skull. Displaced brain can compress the anterior cerebral artery, resulting in stroke and subsequent contralateral hemiparesis (affecting lower extremities more than upper extremities). Furthermore, subfalcine herniation can lead to hydrocephalus and elevated intracranial pressure via compression of the foramen of Monro. Since subfalcine herniation is a process involving the anterior hemispheres, the patient may not experience depressed consciousness (unless the shift is extreme).    

Common causes of subfalcine herniation include either focal mass effect, such as from an arterial bleed, tumor, or abscesses, or diffuse mass effect secondary to generalized cerebral edema.  

Option Analysis

❌ Oculomotor nerve compression:
Incorrect: Herniation of the medial temporal lobe, uncus, and hippocampal gyrus through the tentorial incisura can compress the oculomotor nerve, peduncle, and posterior cerebral artery. This patient instead has evidence of a subfalcine herniation. 
✅ Anterior cerebral artery compression :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Kernohan phenomenon:
Incorrect: Kernohan phenomenon refers to an imaging finding that results from extensive midline shift secondary to mass effect, resulting in the indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. This patient instead has evidence of a subfalcine herniation. 
❌ Duret hemorrhages:
Incorrect: Duret hemorrhages can occur as a complication of central/downward transtentorial  herniation and rupture of penetrating basal arteries to the brainstem. This patient instead has evidence of a subfalcine herniation. 
❌ Cerebral aqueduct obstruction:
Incorrect: Ascending transtentorial herniation can obstruct the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.This patient has evidence of a subfalcine herniation, which can obstruct cerebrospinal fluid outflow of the lateral ventricles via compression of the foramen of Monro.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man undergoes coronary artery bypass grafting. Upon extubation, the patient reports bilateral blindness. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilaterally equal, reactive pupils and a normal fundoscopic exam. MRI of the brain shows wedge-shaped cortical infarcts of both occipital lobes. This patient most likely sustained an infarct in which of the following vascular distributions?

choices.text: Inferior division of the middle cerebral arteries
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery watershed area
Superior division of the middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
This patient’s MRI demonstrates symmetrical infarcts in the occipital watershed region–at the border of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and middle cerebral artery (MCA) distribution of the occipital lobe. Infarction at this watershed region results in cortical blindness.  

Watershed regions are supplied by distal branches of the major cerebral arteries; they are located between regions supplied by the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Watershed regions are vulnerable to ischemia due to low baseline perfusion pressures, and infarcts can occur secondary to sudden decreases in blood pressure or cessation of blood flow through both vessels. Watershed zones are divided into two types:  
  •  Cortical border zones: territories between the anterior and middle cerebral arteries and between the middle and posterior cerebral arteries 
  •  Internal border zones: territories between the superficial and deep branches of the MCA 
 
Patients with watershed infarcts present with signs of systemic hypoperfusion (e.g., tachycardia, low blood pressure, pallor, sweating), diffuse neurologic deterioration, bilateral visual loss (cortical blindness with PCA-MCA watershed region), and/or proximal limb weakness with sparing of the face, hands, and feet (ACA-MCA watershed region). 

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior and posterior communicating arteries:
Incorrect: Saccular aneurysms are often found within the anterior and posterior communicating arteries in the circle of Willis. Anterior communicating artery aneurysms can compress the optic chiasm, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia. 
❌ Inferior division of the middle cerebral arteries:
Incorrect: The inferior division of the middle cerebral artery supplies Wernicke's area in the superior temporal lobe. Ischemia of this area results in aphasia characterized by normal fluency with impaired comprehension and repetition. 
✅ Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery watershed area:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superior division of the middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The superior division of the middle cerebral artery supplies Broca's area in the inferior frontal lobe. Ischemia of this area leads to aphasia characterized by normal comprehension with impaired fluency and repetition. 
❌ Proximal middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The proximal middle cerebral artery supplies portions of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes. Ischemia of this area will lead to global aphasia, characterized by impaired fluency, comprehension, and repetition.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset weakness in the left upper extremity. The patient does not have syncope, dizziness, or urinary incontinence. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes, for which she is taking lisinopril and metformin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and oriented. Physical examination reveals conjugate gaze deviation to the right. There is 3/5 strength in the left upper extremity and 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is performed and shown below:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

A lesion in which of the following anatomic locations explains this patient’s ocular findings?
questions.solution:
A middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke affects the cortical homunculus for the hands, arms, face, causing contralateral upper extremity weakness and sensory loss. Symptoms vary depending on the hemisphere affected, with language disorders seen with strokes in the dominant hemisphere, or hemineglect seen with strokes in the non-dominant hemisphere. In addition, the frontal eye fields (FEF) are located in the cerebral cortex, so associated visual defects are commonly observed. If a middle cerebral artery stroke implicates a frontal eye field, the other eye field predominates, so the eyes deviate to the side affected (eyes look toward the lesion). In this patient, a right-sided MCA lesion (depicted by the yellow arrow) caused left-sided hemiparesis and damage to the right FEF, resulting in right-sided gaze preference.


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Option Analysis

❌ Left frontal eye field:
Incorrect: If a stroke affects a frontal eye field, the affected eye field predominates, so eyes deviate towards the side affected; in this case, the patient’s eyes are deviated to the right, meaning that the left frontal eye field is intact.
❌ Left medial longitudinal fasciculus:
Incorrect: A left medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) lesion results in internuclear ophthalmoplegia, characterized by impaired horizontal eye movement with slow, weak adduction of the affected eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye. This patient’s associated hemiparesis suggests damage to a different anatomic location.
❌ Left paramedian pontine reticular formation:
Incorrect: The paramedian pontine reticular formation refers to a region of the reticular formation immediately ventral to the abducens nucleus, which contains neurons critical for generating horizontal saccades. Damage to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation will prevent the movement of either eye to the left.
❌ Right medial longitudinal fasciculus:
Incorrect: A right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) lesion results in internuclear ophthalmoplegia, which is characterized by impaired horizontal eye movement with slow, weak adduction of the affected eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye. This patient’s associated hemiparesis suggests damage to a different anatomic location.
✅ Right frontal eye field:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right paramedian pontine reticular formation:
Incorrect: The right paramedian pontine reticular formation refers to a region of the reticular formation immediately ventral to the abducens nucleus, which contains neurons critical for generating horizontal saccades. Damage to the right paramedian pontine reticular formation will prevent the movement of either eye to the right.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of visual impairment. The patient has not had headache, trauma, or difficulty with speech, swallowing, or walking. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min (irregularly irregular), respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. On neurological examination, the patient is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Speech is fluent, and the patient follows all commands. Visual field examination findings are shown below.  The remainder of the neurological examination is within normal limits. Perfusion of which of the following regions of the brain is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing–consistent with a stroke of the occipital lobe, supplied by the posterior cerebral artery (PCA).    

The PCA branches off the basilar artery at the level of pontomesencephalic junction and supplies CN III, IV, and midbrain structures. It also supplies the occipital lobe (which contains the primary visual cortex), thalamus, medial temporal lobe, splenium of corpus callosum, parahippocampal gyrus, and fusiform gyrus.    

The primary visual cortex of each hemisphere receives information regarding contralateral visual fields from the ipsilateral geniculate nucleus via optic radiations. Occlusion of the PCA most commonly leads to ischemic injury to the ipsilateral primary visual cortex, producing contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing. The macula is spared because of the collateral blood supply by the middle cerebral artery to the occipital lobe, which processes central visual information.  

Implication of the lateral thalamus can result in contralateral paresthesias and numbness affecting the face, trunk, and limbs. Moreover, a variety of cortical symptoms including dyslexia, visual agnosia (impaired visual recognition of objects), and prosopagnosia (inability to recognize faces) can also occur. 

Option Analysis

❌ Posterolateral thalamus:
Incorrect: A pure sensory stroke is caused by diminished perfusion of the ventral posterolateral and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus. This anatomic region of the brain relays sensory information regarding proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals present with unilateral-sided numbness of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus). 
❌ Parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and/or middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of the ACA or MCA may result in numbness; however, a stroke of the nondominant side more commonly manifests with symptoms of contralateral neglect. Meanwhile, infarction of the dominant side manifests with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia.  
✅ Occipital lobe:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior limb of the internal capsule:
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in a pure motor stroke, the most common lacunar stroke (> 50%). Patients typically present with contralateral hemiparesis without sensory loss or cortical signs (e.g. aphasia).  
❌ Medial medulla:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome. This condition usually presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left-sided numbness and unsteady gait. The patient was having dinner with family one hour ago when she suddenly developed numbness in the left side of her body and could no longer sense the temperature of her food. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient takes metformin, glipizide, amlodipine, losartan, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates deficits in touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature on the left side of the body and face. Motor strength and speech are normal. Romberg sign is positive. An ischemic stroke involving which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of her clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset, unilateral sensory deficits (touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature) without cortical signs or motor deficits. A positive Romberg test suggests an additional deficit in proprioception. This presentation is suggestive of a pure sensory stroke involving the thalamic nuclei.  

The thalamus is a component of the diencephalon that lies on either side of the third ventricle and serves as the site of integration of somatosensory information. The thalamic nuclei include the ventral posteromedial nucleus (VPM) and the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL). The former receives afferent neuronal fibers from the trigeminal lemniscus and the gustatory pathway, while the latter receives afferent information from the dorsal column pathway (medial and lateral lemniscus) and from the lateral spinothalamic tract. These pathways carry sensory information regarding vibration, proprioception, pressure, pain, taste, light touch, and temperature. Efferent neuronal fibers from these nuclei terminate in the primary somatosensory cortex.  

Clinical manifestations of an ischemic thalamic stroke include loss of touch, pain, temperature, vibration, proprioception, and tactile discrimination over the contralateral half of the body (including sensory loss over the contralateral side of the face without motor deficits or cortical signs). Thalamic lesions are frequently the result of a lacunar stroke (small vessel microatheroma or lipohyalinosis). Risk factors for these lesions include hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia (all of which are present in this patient).  



Option Analysis

❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The hypothalamus is the site of regulation of temperature, hunger, satiety, endocrine functions, circadian rhythm, emotion, behavior, and sexual drive. It is not involved in relaying somatosensory information.
✅ Thalamus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Internal capsule is a subcortical white matter structure that relays sensory-motor information from the brainstem and contralateral body to the brain. Strokes involving the posterior limb of the internal capsule present with pure motor or mixed sensory-motor deficits, as opposed to pure sensory deficits. 
❌ Brainstem:
Incorrect: Stroke syndromes involving the brainstem are accompanied by signs and symptoms of autonomic, corticospinal (motor), and/or cranial nerve(s) involvement. Pure sensory deficits are not usually seen.
❌ Cerebral cortex:
Incorrect: Cortical strokes involving the somatosensory areas of the brain can be differentiated from thalamic strokes by the presence of cortical symptoms, which include aphasia, neglect, and behavioral changes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner due to dizziness, difficulty walking, and severe headache for two hours. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 182/106 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 20/min. Neurologic examination demonstrates right-sided dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing and right-sided dysrhythmia with rapid finger tapping. The patient appears to have difficulty with balance and a propensity to fall to the right side. Motor strength and sensation are symmetric and preserved bilaterally, and no speech deficits are apparent. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s brain lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a lateral cerebellar hemisphere lesion resulting in ipsilateral deficits (imbalance and falling toward the side of the lesion), limb ataxia, and intention tremor.

Lateral lesions of the cerebellum affect the cortex of the cerebellar hemispheres and deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei. Cerebellar efferent fibers first cross to the contralateral side and the ipsilateral side. Together, these structures assist in planning and programming movements that influence the proximal flexor muscles of the upper extremities.

Clinically, lateral cerebellar lesions result in ipsilateral limb ataxia (loss of coordination of the limb on the same side as the lesion), which can lead to intention tremor (involuntary, trembling movements that occur with voluntary movements), dysmetria (loss of coordination that presents as the overshoot or undershoot of the intended position of the extremities), dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform fast alternating movements), decreased muscle tone of the extremities and loss of balance, with a tendency to fall towards the side of the lesion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cerebellar vermis  :
Incorrect: Lesions that affect midline structures of the cerebellum, such as the vermis or the flocculonodular lobe, cause problems such as truncal ataxia, cerebellar gait, and the proximal muscle groups. This patient’s intention tremor and limb ataxia suggest an alternative structure.  
✅ Lateral cerebellar hemisphere  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral medulla  :
Incorrect: A lateral medullary infarct can occur due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar or vertebral artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain and temperature of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vestibulocerebellar impairment, and Horner syndrome.  
❌ Medial mid-pons  :
Incorrect: A medial mid-pontine infarction presents with contralateral ataxia and hemiparesis of the face, trunk, and limbs. There is a variable loss of contralateral tactile and position sense. This patient’s intention tremor and ipsilateral limb ataxia with preserved sensations suggest an alternative structure.  
❌ Medial medulla  :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome presents with contralateral paralysis of the arm and leg and tongue deviation towards the lesion.

questions.text: A 68-year-old, right-handed man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate sudden onset weakness. The patient awoke with left-hand clumsiness that rapidly progressed to left-sided weakness, affecting the left arm more than the left leg. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s last refill of medications was one year ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 200/110 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient has slurred speech, left-sided facial weakness sparing the forehead, 2/5 muscle strength in the left upper limb, and 4/5 muscle strength in the left lower limb. Right-sided strength and sensation are normal. A right-sided infarct localized to the paramedian pontine base is seen on MRI. Which of the following additional findings will likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has an infarct of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), which is located in the pons and supplied by the paramedian branches of the basilar artery.

The PPRF is the subcortical lateral gaze center, which normally receives input from the contralateral frontal eye field to stimulate the lateral rectus muscle of the ipsilateral eye via the ipsilateral abducens nucleus. This signal is also transmitted to the medial longitudinal fasciculus of the contralateral oculomotor nuclei to stimulate the medial rectus muscle of the contralateral eye. Together, these signals result in both eyes' simultaneous, conjugate movement towards the left or the right.

Common causes of lesions to the PPRF include ischemic or hemorrhagic strokes of the paramedian branches of the basilar artery. When these lesions occur, both eyes deviate toward the contralateral side, away from the brain lesion. On the contrary, the frontal eye field lesions produce similar symptoms where both eyes deviate but to the ipsilateral side, towards the brain lesion. For example, when the eyes deviate to the right, the lesion can either involve the left PPRF or the right frontal eye field.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bitemporal hemianopia:
Incorrect: The x-shaped optic chiasm serves as the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure results in bitemporal hemianopia. Common etiologies include pituitary tumors, craniopharyngiomas, and aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery.  
❌ Eye deviation to the right  :
Incorrect: Destructive lesions of the frontal eye field (e.g. middle cerebral artery stroke) cause the eyes to look toward the side of brain lesion (i.e. away from the side of hemiplegia). The middle cerebral artery does not supply blood to the paramedian pontine base.  
✅ Eye deviation to the left  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing  :
Incorrect: Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing is characteristic of posterior cerebral artery infarction. Other features include alexia without agraphia when the dominant hemisphere is affected.  
❌ Vertical gaze palsy  :
Incorrect: Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome is characterized by limitation of upward gaze with a downward gaze preference, bilateral eyelid lid retraction, and near-light dissociation (i.e. pupils react to accommodation but not to light). These findings often result from compression of the pretectal region of the midbrain (most likely from a pinealoma).

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a syncopal event while walking to the bathroom. The patient's past medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On initial evaluation, the patient is unresponsive to verbal or tactile stimuli. There are no observable cranial nerve functions. Corneal and gag reflexes are absent on examination. The patient is subsequently intubated and admitted to the ICU. Two days later, the patient’s nurse reports the patient is able to open his eyes and respond to stimuli with vertical eye movements. A noncontrast CT of the brain is demonstrated below:

 

 Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

A stroke in which of the following vascular structures is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
At the base of the medulla, both vertebral arteries fuse to create the basilar artery. As the basilar artery ascends, it yields the following branches:

  •  Anterior inferior cerebellar artery, or AICA, which supplies the lateral pons and part of the cerebellum  
  •  Labyrinthine (internal auditory) artery, which supplies the cochlea and labyrinth 
  •  Pontine arteries, which supply the mid-pons and upper and lower portions of the pons 
  •  Right and left superior cerebellar arteries, which supply a part of the pons laterally and the superior part of the cerebellum  
  •  Right and left posterior cerebral arteries, or PCAs, which supply the occipital lobe 
If the basilar artery becomes occluded, damage to the pons often results in locked-in syndrome, wherein the patient becomes quadriplegic and mute. Additionally, loss of horizontal eye movements occurs due to implication of the paramedian pontine reticular formation, with preservation of vertical eye movements.
