Despite these devastating neurologic consequences, consciousness is preserved due to preservation of the reticular activating system, or RAS.



Option Analysis

❌ Anterior spinal artery:
Incorrect: A stroke affecting the anterior spinal artery causes infarction of the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord with development of contralateral paralysis of both upper and lower extremities and  contralateral loss of pain and temperature.
✅ Basilar artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A left middle cerebral artery stroke would cause right-sided weakness. This patient is presenting with complete loss of motor function and sensation.
❌ Lenticulostriate arteries:
Incorrect: Lacunar strokes occur secondary to ischemia within the lenticulostriate arteries, which are  a collection of small perforating arteries arising from the anterior part of the circle of Willis. Patients with lesions in these vessels present with varying symptoms including hemiparesis or hemisensory loss; however, this patient is presenting with complete loss of motor function and sensation.
❌ Right middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right middle cerebral artery stroke would cause left-sided weakness. This patient is presenting with complete loss of motor function and sensation, which suggests a stroke in a different vessel.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the clinic for evaluation of memory problems. The patient has become increasingly forgetful and has trouble remembering recent events, but memory of remote events remains intact. The patient is able to cook for himself and has no trouble getting around the neighborhood. The patient does not have depressive symptoms. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which amlodipine, valsartan, metformin, insulin and atorvastatin are prescribed. The patient has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg. Mental status examination is significant for anterograde amnesia. Pathologic involvement of which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
This patient presents with isolated anterograde amnesia (difficulty remembering recent events) without dysfunction in performing activities of daily living; he has most likely suffered damage to the hippocampus. Past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension, active smoking, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia puts this patient at risk of having significant atherosclerotic disease.  

The hippocampus serves as a component of the limbic system, which is involved in the formation and retrieval of recent memories and in the conversion of recent memory to long-term memory. The hippocampus receives its blood supply from the terminal branches of the anterior choroidal artery and posterior cerebral artery and is in a watershed area, making it particularly susceptible to ischemic damage. Injury to the hippocampus results in anterograde amnesia (the inability to form new memories) with preservation of remote past memories.  



Option Analysis

❌ Nucleus basalis:
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis is involved in the production of acetylcholine for the cerebral cortex. Decreased production of acetylcholine is believed to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer disease. This patient presents with isolated memory loss without dysfunction in activities of daily living and is therefore less likely to have Alzheimer dementia.
❌ Ventral tegmentum:
Incorrect: The ventral tegmentum provides dopaminergic input, and decreased activity can be associated with Parkinson disease.
❌ Raphe nucleus:
Incorrect: The raphe nucleus provides serotonergic input, and decreased activity of this region of the brain is sometimes associated with depression.
✅ Hippocampus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion to the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. It results in spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter for evaluation of left-sided weakness for one hour. She does not have a headache or blurred vision. She has a past medical history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes, and coronary artery disease. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, metformin, and aspirin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg. Examination demonstrates a left facial droop, 3/5 left-sided strength, and 3+ deep tendon reflexes. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration, as well as two-point discrimination, is normal. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of the pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with a lacunar stroke secondary to infarction of the genus and anterior 2/3rd of the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Specifically, lacunar strokes are non-cortical infarcts, characterized by the absence of cortical signs (e.g., no aphasia, hemianopsia, agnosia, apraxia), secondary to ischemia of lenticulostriate arteries. These blood vessels are deep penetrating branches of the major cerebral arteries that supply deep brain nuclei, including the thalamus, basal ganglia, pons, and white matter of the internal capsule. Damage and subsequent ischemia via these arteries occurs largely due to hyaline arteriolosclerosis and chronic hypertension or diabetes mellitus.  

Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule is the most common type of lacunar stroke and may manifest with the following clinical features:  
  • Pure motor stroke: contralateral weakness equally affecting the face, arm, and leg 
  •  Pure sensory stroke: contralateral numbness of the face, arm, and leg  
  •  Sensorimotor stroke: contralateral weakness and numbness of the face, arm, and leg (absence cortical signs) 
  •  Dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome: facial weakness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and slight weakness and clumsiness of one hand. 
  •  Ataxic hemiparesis: ipsilateral weakness and limb ataxia that is out of proportion to the motor deficit. 

Option Analysis

✅ Internal capsule:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Medulla:
Incorrect: Lateral medullary infarction typically occurs due to posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion. It is characterized by vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, bulbar weakness, and Horner syndrome. 
❌ Thalamus:
Incorrect: A lacunar stroke of the posterolateral thalamus typically presents with sudden-onset contralateral sensory loss involving all sensory modalities (i.e. pure sensory stroke). This patient has pure motor hemiparesis. 
❌ Midbrain:
Incorrect: Midbrain strokes present with ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy, ataxia (superior cerebellar peduncle), and contralateral hemiparesis (cerebral peduncle). 
❌ Postcentral gyrus:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the middle or anterior cerebral artery can result in contralateral sensory loss (due to infarction of the somatosensory cortex in the postcentral gyrus), hemiparesis (due to primary motor cortex injury), and cortical signs.

questions.text: A 72-year-old right-handed person is brought to the clinic to establish care. The patient was recently discharged from the hospital where they were admitted for the management of a stroke. The patient initially presented with left-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the right middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy as they presented outside of the administration window. The patient participated in physical therapy during hospitalization and reports that muscle strength has improved significantly. The patient reports that they feel like they are coming back to their baseline. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength of 4/5 on the left side. Dress and appearance on the left side of their body appears unkempt. When asked to draw a clock and copy a box and a flower, their drawings appear as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, they only draw the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (inattention to the left side of the body) most likely has spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. This patient also exhibits anosognosia (unawareness of neural defect). Together, these features suit a diagnosis of hemispatial neglect syndrome.

Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from injury to the inferior parietal lobe in the non-dominant hemisphere. This area houses the somatosensory association area and is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Injury to this area ultimately results in a patient who is unable to integrate somatic and visual inputs and cannot appreciate an image on the opposite side of the body.  

Clinical manifestations include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body and anosognosia (individual is unaware of neural defect). Affected individuals may fail to shave, wash, and dress the contralateral half of their bodies. When asked to draw a clock, the patient's drawing might only show numbers on one side of the clock or all 12 numbers might be on one half with the other half distorted (construction apraxia).  

Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.
✅ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gerstmann syndrome:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome is a dominant hemispheric stroke syndrome that usually results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right lower extremity weakness. The patient awoke this morning with difficulty standing from the bed. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus and a myocardial infarction with drug-eluting stent placement. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past thirty years. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 200/96 mm Hg. Neurologic examination reveals 0/5 strength of the right lower extremity, 3+ deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign. Sensation is decreased throughout the right foot and leg. The left lower extremity and bilateral upper extremities are neurologically intact. Which of the following labeled vascular structures is most likely implicated given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient likely suffered an ischemic stroke of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) territory. The ACA supplies the medial aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes, a region which controls the ipsilateral lower extremity motor and sensory cortices. Occlusion of the ACA results in contralateral motor and sensory deficits, with the lower limb affected more than the upper limb. Notably, bilateral ACA occlusion can cause significant behavioral symptoms (e.g. abulia) and urinary incontinence due to damage to the frontal micturition center (e.g. medial frontal lobe/cingulate gyrus). 

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Saccular aneurysms are often found within the anterior and posterior communicating arteries in the circle of Willis. Anterior communicating artery aneurysms can compress the optic chiasm, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia. 
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ C:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction results in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery. 
❌ D:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) can result in lateral pontine syndrome. Patients typically present with a lower motor neuron facial nerve lesion, vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral sensorineural loss, and Horner syndrome. 
❌ E:
Incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion can result in damage to the base of the pons–an area of the brainstem that houses the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, as well as the paramedian tegmentum. Patients typically develop quadriplegia, bulbar dysfunction (e.g., facial weakness, dysarthria), and oculomotor deficits (e.g. horizontal gaze palsy).

questions.text: A 85-year-old left-handed woman is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden involuntary body movements. The patient states that she is having a hard time controlling movements of her right leg. Symptoms started a few hours ago. Past medical history is notable for diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a myocardial infarction five years ago. The patient takes metformin, insulin, amlodipine, valsartan, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient smokes one to two cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 160/93 mmHg. Physical examination shows intermittent wide flinging movements of the patient’s proximal right arm and leg. Damage to which of the following parts of the brain is the most likely cause of these abnormal body movements?
questions.solution:
Hemiballismus is a form of  involuntary movement associated with diseases afflicting the subthalamic nuclei. These movements are typically unilateral, irregular, and of large amplitude (violent flinging movement of limbs) that become more prominent with action. A lacunar stroke involving penetrating branches of a large cerebral artery supplying the subthalamus is the most common etiology of hemiballismus. Risk factors for lacunar strokes include hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. 

The basal ganglia consists of gray matter masses within the cerebral hemispheres. These include the caudate, putamen, globus pallidus, and amygdaloid nucleus. The subthalamic nuclei, substantia nigra, and the red nucleus are structures functionally related to the basal ganglia. Physiologically, the subthalamic nucleus sends excitatory signals to the globus pallidus that, in turn, inhibits the thalamus and serves as an important modulator of basal ganglia output to regulate movement.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left subthalamic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus presents with left-sided hemiballismus.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus is the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior left parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
❌ Bilateral amygdala:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.

questions.text: An 81-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset weakness in the right upper and right lower extremity. The patient’s partner states she fell while walking to the kitchen and several minutes later noticed that the patient urinated on herself. The partner denies shaking of the limbs or head trauma. The patient denies confusion, loss of consciousness, or tongue biting. Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she is taking lisinopril and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and oriented. Physical examination reveals full visual fields with no defects. There is 4/5 strength in the right upper extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Finger-to-nose testing is normal and without dysdiadochokinesia. Which of the following vessels labeled  in the diagram below is most likely implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with several cerebrovascular disease risk factors (e.g. hypertension, hyperlipidemia), right-sided hemiparesis predominantly affecting the lower extremity, and urinary incontinence. Given these findings, this patient likely suffered from a left anterior cerebral artery stroke.

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the medial and dorsal aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes as well as the postcentral gyrus and precentral gyrus. Therefore, an anterior cerebral artery stroke predominantly affects the cortical homunculus for the feet and legs, causing contralateral paralysis and sensory loss. Additionally, a stroke of the ACA commonly compromises the medial frontal micturition center, causing activation of the pontine and spinal micturition centers, with subsequent urinary incontinence.

  

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This answer is the right anterior cerebral artery, which is unlikely to be the source of this patient’s right-sided hemiparesis. A stroke in this vessel would present with contralateral symptoms (e.g. left-sided hemiparesis).
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ C:
Incorrect: This answer is the right internal carotid artery, which bifurcates into the major arteries of the brain, including the right anterior cerebral artery, right middle cerebral artery, and right posterior cerebral artery. A stroke of the ICA is rare and manifests with severe hemiplegia, sensory disturbance, and obtundation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: This answer is the left internal carotid artery, which bifurcates into the major arteries of the brain, including the left anterior cerebral artery, left middle cerebral artery, and left posterior cerebral artery. A stroke of the ICA is rare and manifests with severe hemiplegia, sensory disturbance, and obtundation.
❌ E:
Incorrect: This answer is the basilar artery, which supplies the pons. Patients with basilar artery stroke  develop hemiparesis or quadriparesis, facial palsies, dizziness, headache, and speech disturbance.

questions.text: A 68-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided weakness and numbness. The patient woke up with right hand clumsiness that rapidly progressed to right-sided weakness, affecting the right arm more than the right leg. Past medical history includes hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has a 20-pack/year smoking history. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 138/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 146/86 mm Hg. The patient speaks clearly, but his sentences are incomprehensible. Neurological examination demonstrates impaired two-point discrimination to light touch in the right arm, right facial weakness sparing the forehead, 2/5 muscle strength in the right upper extremity, and 4/5 muscle strength in the right lower extremity. Left-sided strength is preserved, and visual fields are within normal limits. The etiology of this patient's symptoms likely occurred secondary to ischemia of an artery supplying which of the following anatomic regions?
questions.solution:
This patient likely suffered an ischemic stroke involving the territory supplied by the middle cerebral artery (MCA). The MCA supplies the bulk of the lateral surface of the hemisphere, where the superior division supplies lateral inferior frontal lobe, inferior division supplies lateral temporal lobe, and the deep branches supply the basal ganglia as well as the internal capsule.  

Patients with an MCA stroke typically present with contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss involving the face and upper limb due to infarction of corresponding motor and sensory cortices. The contralateral lower limb is less affected given the distribution of the sensory-motor homunculus (lower limb supplied by the anterior cerebral artery). If the stroke involves the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, the speech centers of the brain are often implicated as well, resulting in expressive or receptive aphasia due to infarction of the Broca and Wernicke areas, respectively.  

Other features of MCA stroke include spatial neglect of the contralateral side due to damage to the non-dominant parietal lobe and contralateral homonymous quadrantanopia due to damage to the optic radiations in the subcortical temporoparietal lobe.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cingulate gyrus:
Incorrect: The cingulate gyrus is supplied via the anterior cerebral artery. Infarction of the cingulate gyrus would present with motor and sensory deficits of the contralateral lower extremity only. 
❌ Globus pallidus:
Incorrect: The globus pallidus is supplied by the lenticulostriate artery; however, a lacunar infarct of this artery presents with contralateral weakness and sensory loss in the upper and lower extremities. This patient has relative preservation of the lower extremity motor and sensory innervation, in addition to speech impairment and facial weakness. 
❌ Lateral medulla:
Incorrect: The lateral medulla is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery; however, a stroke of this artery would present with impaired sensation of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body. 
❌ Lingual gyrus:
Incorrect: The lingual gyrus is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery; however, a stroke of this artery would present with visual defects such as hemianopsia. 
✅ Temporal gyrus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 75-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes, for which the patient takes amlodipine, chlorthalidone, and insulin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 180/99 mmHg. On examination, right upper and lower extremity motor strength is 1/5. The patient has difficulty answering questions and appears to be frustrated by this inability to communicate. The patient is able to speak a few words, but the speech is non-fluent. She is able to comprehend 2-step instructions but is unable to repeat phrases. Which of the following best describes the type of aphasia observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with difficulty answering questions and frustration driven by their inability to communicate (expressive aphasia). The patient is able to speak a few words, but speech is non-fluent. The patient is able to comprehend 2-step instructions; however, they are unable to repeat phrases, making Broca aphasia the most likely cause of the language impairment.  

Broca’s area is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Efferent pathways from Broca’s area connect to the muscles of the larynx, mouth, tongue, soft palate, and respiratory muscles to formulate speech. Broca aphasia most commonly results from an ischemic stroke secondary to anterior MCA branch occlusion. Other etiologies include trauma, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease. Typical clinical features include non-fluent, sparse speech as well as agrammatism, intact comprehension, and impaired repetition. Hemiparesis (as in this patient) and oral apraxia may occur due to ischemia sustained to the adjacent motor and supplementary areas.  



Option Analysis

❌ Transcortical sensory aphasia:
Incorrect: Transcortical sensory aphasia results from insults to the inferior temporal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech with intact ability to repeat but poor comprehension.  
❌ Global aphasia:
Incorrect: Global aphasia results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, Broca’s area, and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes non-fluent speech, poor comprehension, and impaired repetition.
❌ Conduction aphasia:
Incorrect: Conduction aphasia results from a lesion involving the arcuate fasciculus. The arcuate fasciculus is the bundle of nerve fibers between Broca’s and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech and preserved comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech often contains frequent phonemic errors.
❌ Wernicke aphasia:
Incorrect: Wernicke’s area is involved in processing and understanding of written and spoken language. It is supplied by the posterior MCA branch and located within the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Damage to Wernicke’s area manifests with fluent speech and poor comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech sounds voluminous but without meaning, and the patient often appears unaware of the deficit. A right superior visual field defect may be present as well.
✅ Broca aphasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation following a motor vehicle accident. Upon arrival the patient has a Glasgow coma scale of 9. His temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 78/48 mmHg. Chest x-ray demonstrates several fractured ribs bilaterally, and a CT brain is without signs of bleeding or hemorrhage. The patient is resuscitated with administration of type O negative blood and norepinephrine; however, he remains persistently hypotensive with a repeat systolic blood pressure of 49/25 mmHg. Which of the following anatomic structures is most susceptible to injury given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Global ischemic-hypoxic brain injury can occur in the setting of profound hypotension, hypoxia, or a combination of both. In the setting of hypotension, ischemia to the brain is typically observed when systolic pressures fall below 50 mm Hg, such as in cardiac arrest or refractory shock. Patient outcomes vary directly with both the severity and duration of the hypotensive event. The most susceptible locations of ischemic injury to the brain are those with poor collateral circulation and include the following:

  •  Pyramidal cells of the hippocampus  
  •  Pyramidal cells of the neocortex 
  •  Purkinje cells of the cerebellum 

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pituitary:
Incorrect: The pituitary gland is not as susceptible to ischemia when compared with the hippocampus;  however, in the setting of a  pituitary adenoma, apoplexy can occur, which results in massive hemorrhage of the organ.
✅ Hippocampus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pons:
Incorrect: The pons is not as susceptible to ischemia as the hippocampus due to collateral blood supply from the anterior and posterior spinal cord. 
❌ Anterior pituitary :
Incorrect: The pituitary gland is rarely affected by ischemia, given its central location and collateral vascular supply.
❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: Like the anterior pituitary, the hypothalamus is rarely affected by ischemia given its central location and collateral vascular supply.

questions.text: A 68-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department following sudden onset weakness in his right arm and dysarthria. The patient’s partner states, “He suddenly dropped his cup of coffee while walking to the kitchen table and was unable to respond to me, so I called 911.” Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert but appears frustrated by not being able to speak. The patient blinks on command. Physical examination demonstrates full visual fields without deficits. Neurologic evaluation demonstrates 2/5 strength in the right upper extremity and 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Pathology to which of the following anatomic structures is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
A middle cerebral artery stroke affects the cortical homunculus for the hands, arms, and face, causing contralateral upper extremity weakness and sensory loss. In addition, symptoms vary depending on which hemisphere (dominant vs. non-dominant) is involved:

  •  The dominant hemisphere, which is usually the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals, contains the language centers: the Broca and Wernicke areas. If the Broca area is implicated, expressive aphasia may ensue--meaning patients are unable to articulate responses. If the Wernicke area becomes implicated, receptive aphasia may ensue--meaning patients lose the ability to comprehend language. 
  •  If the non-dominant hemisphere is affected, which is typically the right side, patients may develop hemineglect--wherein the patients are unaware of one side of his/her body. 

 

Option Analysis

❌ Left anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A left anterior cerebral artery stroke can also cause right-sided weakness; however, the weakness predominantly affects the lower limb. Additionally, this patient’s difficulty speaking suggests a stroke in a different vessel.
✅ Left middle cerebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A left posterior cerebral artery stroke causes right hemianopsia, which is absent in this patient.
❌ Right anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right anterior cerebral artery stroke causes left-sided weakness predominantly affecting the lower limb.
❌ Right middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right middle cerebral artery stroke would cause left-sided weakness, not right sided weakness.
❌ Right posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: A right posterior cerebral artery stroke results in left hemianopsia, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden-onset ataxia and facial weakness. Her partner states they were eating dinner when the patient suddenly lost her ability to chew her food. The patient indicates associated numbness to the right side of her face. The patient's medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension as well as a 35-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right pupil is constricted with associated drooping of the right eyelid. There are no visual deficits, nystagmus, or extraocular muscle weakness. The jaw is deviated to the right. There is a diminished sensation to pinprick over the right side of the face. Which of the following anatomic locations is most likely implicated given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset facial paralysis and numbness, suggestive of a stroke, particularly of the brainstem given the associated cranial nerve deficits. A stroke that affects the perforating branches of the basilar and anterior inferior cerebellar arteries (AICA) leads to lateral pontine syndrome, in which the following structures are affected:

  •  Trigeminal nuclei and nerve root 
    •  Complete ipsilateral trigeminal paralysis, manifesting in: 
      •  Paralysis of the muscles of mastication 
      •  Jaw deviation to the paretic side (due to unopposed action of the intact lateral pterygoid) 
      •  Facial hemianesthesia (loss of pain, temperature, touch, and proprioception) 
      •  Loss of the corneal reflex (afferent limb of CN V1) 
  •  Middle cerebellar peduncle 
    •  Ipsilateral limb and gait ataxia

Option Analysis

❌ Medial medulla:
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome results in contralateral hemiparesis of the trunk and extremities, contralateral loss of proprioception, tactile sensation, and vibratory sensation, as well as ipsilateral flaccid paralysis of the tongue.
❌ Medial pons:
Incorrect: Medial pontine syndrome, also known as Foville syndrome, results in contralateral hemiplegia (with facial sparing) due to corticospinal tract involvement, ipsilateral peripheral-type facial palsy, and inability to move the eyes conjugately to the ipsilateral side.
❌ Lateral medulla:
Incorrect: Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, occurs with infarction of the lateral medulla. Clinically, this syndrome is characterized by dysphagia, hoarseness and decreased gag reflex, vertigo and nystagmus, ipsilateral decreased sensation of pain and temperature of the face,  along with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the trunk and extremities.
✅ Lateral pons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Medial midbrain:
Incorrect: Ischemia of the medial midbrain, also known as Weber syndrome, results from occlusion of midbrain branches of the posterior cerebral artery. Patients typically present with oculomotor nerve deficits, contralateral weakness of the lower face (CN VII), tongue (CN XII) and palate (CN X), along with contralateral hemiparesis of the trunk and limbs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to confusion. The symptoms began two hours ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 162/85 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. On physical examination, the patient is oriented to self but not place or time. Neuroimaging reveals an occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery. Which of the following additional physical examination findings will most likely be present?

choices.text: Paralysis of the bilateral lower extremities
Reduced strength in the left lower extremity
Weakness and loss of sensation in the left upper extremity
Loss of cough and gag reflexes

questions.solution:
This patient has had a right middle cerebral artery stroke, which is part of the anterior cerebral circulation. The stroke can result in motor and sensory deficits of the left upper extremity.  

The brain’s blood supply can be divided into the anterior and posterior circulation. The anterior circulation originates from the internal carotid arteries, which travel through the carotid canal of the temporal bone and into the cranial cavity. Once within the cranial cavity, the internal carotid artery gives off two important branches.    

The first is the middle cerebral artery (MCA), which supplies blood to the lateral frontal and parietal lobes and the temporal lobes. These areas of the brain contain the portions of the motor and sensory cortex that control the face and upper extremities. As a result, patients with an MCA stroke can develop contralateral upper extremity and facial weakness and sensory loss.  

The second is the anterior cerebral artery (ACA), which supplies the medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes. These areas of the brain contain the portions of the motor and sensory cortex that control the lower extremities. As a result, an ACA stroke can cause contralateral lower extremity weakness and sensory loss.  

Option Analysis

❌ Paralysis of the bilateral lower extremities:
Incorrect: This patient has an occlusion of the middle cerebral artery, which supplies blood to the lateral portions of the brain. In contrast, the parts of the brain that regulate the motor function of the lower extremities are located medially and supplied by the anterior cerebral artery. Additionally, this patient is more likely to have unilateral symptoms than bilateral symptoms.
❌ Reduced strength in the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: The primary motor cortex is located within the precentral gyrus. The medial portions of the precentral gyrus regulate the movement of the lower extremities and receive blood from the anterior cerebral artery. Therefore, an occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (as opposed to the middle cerebral artery) would result in lower extremity strength deficits.
✅ Weakness and loss of sensation in the left upper extremity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left-sided hemianopia with macular sparing:
Incorrect: A posterior cerebral artery stroke can lead to occipital lobe infarction manifesting with contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing. In contrast, this patient has an occlusion of the middle cerebral artery, which does not supply blood to the occipital lobe.
❌ Loss of cough and gag reflexes:
Incorrect: Pathologies leading to brainstem infarction, such as a posterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke, can manifest with the loss of cough and gag reflexes. In contrast, this patient has a middle cerebral artery stroke. The middle cerebral artery provides blood supply to the lateral cerebral cortex, subcortical structures (e.g. basal ganglia), and parts of the internal capsule, but not the brainstem.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following sudden onset, right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 156/90 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates flaccid paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities, tongue deviation to the left, slurred speech, hyperreflexic deep tendon reflexes on the right, as well as decreased right-sided proprioception. Sensation is intact and the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following anatomic areas of the brain is most likely affected given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with complete upper and lower limb paralysis, decreased proprioception, and deviation of the tongue with protrusion, suggestive of medial medullary syndrome. This condition often arises secondary to infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery.  

The anterior spinal artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and lower medulla at the midline. The vessel lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord with both penetrating and circumferential branches. Clinical features of medial medullary ischemia include:  

  • Contralateral hemiparesis due to involvement of the lateral corticospinal tract. 
  • Sensory symptoms related to ischemia of the medial lemniscus include decreased contralateral proprioception and pressure vibratory sensation. 
  • Ipsilateral tongue paralysis is the least common but most topographically localizing sign of medial medullary infarction and is due to infarction of the hypoglossal nucleus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Dominant parietal lobe  :
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome results from damage to the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal lobe and is characterized by agraphia (inability to write), acalculia (inability to carry out mathematical calculations), finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation.  
❌ Dorsolateral medulla:
Incorrect: Ischemic injury to the dorsolateral medulla can result in Wallenberg syndrome, secondary to infarction of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain/temperature over the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vertigo, ipsilateral limb ataxia, and Horner syndrome.  
✅ Medial medulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in a pure motor stroke. Patients typically present with contralateral hemiparesis without sensory loss or cortical signs (e.g. aphasia). The most common etiology of a lacunar stroke is hypertension.  
❌ Dorsolateral thalamus:
Incorrect: Acute strokes of the dorsolateral thalamus typically present with contralateral hemisensory loss. Patients often develop significant pain on the side of their deficit (thalamic pain syndrome) weeks to months following the initial insult.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office due to intermittent heaviness and paresthesias of the right arm. The patient has experienced multiple episodes over the past two months, especially while playing table tennis. Each episode is associated with nausea, dizziness, and visual disturbance. The patient has not had any falls or loss of consciousness. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes for the past forty years and drinks alcohol occasionally. Orthostatic vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates decreased radial and brachial pulses of the right upper extremity when compared to the left upper extremity. Skin over the right upper extremity feels cooler than the left. The remainder of the cardiopulmonary and neurologic exam are within normal limits. CT angiogram is performed and reveals a condition that results in reversal of blood flow through a vascular structure. Reverse blood flow through which of the following vessels is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with subclavian steal syndrome (SSS)--a constellation of signs and symptoms that arise secondary to retrograde blood flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery or internal thoracic artery due to stenosis and/or occlusion of the subclavian artery. In this condition, the affected arm is often supplied by blood flowing in a retrograde direction down the ipsilateral vertebral artery at the expense of the vertebrobasilar circulation.  

Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque in the right subclavian artery is the most likely culprit of his symptoms. Reduced blood flow through the subclavian artery results in symptoms of recurrent heaviness with exertion, paresthesias, as well as decreased pulses and cooler skin.  

Over time, stenosis of the subclavian artery increases in blood flow through the contralateral vertebral artery to the basilar artery, followed by retrograde flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery, away from the brainstem. Ultimately, this may result in presyncopal symptoms with exertion of the affected arm including lightheadedness, nausea, and blurred vision. Other etiologies of SSS include Takayasu arteritis, Giant cell arteritis, and thoracic aortic dissection.  

Option Analysis

❌ Right subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), he most likely has an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque of the right subclavian artery. This explains the heaviness, paresthesia, decreased pulses, and cooler skin of her right arm. Blood flow is blocked rather than reversed in this vessel.  
✅ Right vertebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left vertebral artery:
Incorrect: Reduced blood flow to the stenosed side is compensated for by contralateral circulation (from the left vertebral artery in this case). In this case, there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side (left) to the affected side (right) via the vertebral arteries.  
❌ Left subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Although the left subclavian artery compensates for reduced blood flow in the right subclavian artery, it is not the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Left posterior cerebral artery  :
Incorrect: Reversed flow in the left posterior cerebral artery results in reduced perfusion to the left occipital lobe. This may result in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of stroke-like symptoms. The patient states, “My face appeared twisted this morning.” She also reports persistent vertigo, difficulty walking, and impaired hearing from the left ear. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 166/90 mmHg. The patient falls to the left when asked to sit without support. Physical examination demonstrates drooping of the left face and loss of the left nasolabial fold. The patient is able to wrinkle the forehead. Further neurologic examination demonstrates partial ptosis and miosis of the left eye, nystagmus, reduced pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the face and right side of the body, and sensorineural hearing loss on the left. Hearing on the right side is intact. Which of the following vascular structures is most likely implicated given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent lateral pontine syndrome most likely due to the occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Clinical features of lateral pontine syndrome include:
  
  • Vestibulocerebellar symptoms such as nystagmus, vertigo, and difficulty sitting upright without support (falling to the side of lesion) 
  • Loss of pain and temperature sensation of the ipsilateral face (spinal trigeminal nucleus and tract) and contralateral trunk/limbs (spinothalamic tract) 
  • Paralysis of the face (LMN lesion vs UMN lesion in cortical stroke), ↓ lacrimation, ↓ salivation and ↓ taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue 
  • Ipsilateral Horner (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis) due to damage of sympathetic fibers innervating the head and neck 
  •  Ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria due to the involvement of middle and inferior cerebellar peduncle 
  • Ipsilateral sensorineural deafness due to the occlusion of labyrinthine arteries, a branch of AICA 

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Saccular aneurysms are often found in both the anterior and posterior communicating arteries of the circle of Willis. Anterior communicating artery aneurysms often compress the central optic chiasm, resulting in symptoms of bitemporal hemianopsia.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Ischemia of the anterior cerebral artery often results in contralateral motor and sensory deficits, with the lower limbs affected more than the upper limbs.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction typically results in contralateral hemianopia, secondary to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion usually damages the base of the pons, which houses the corticospinal/ corticobulbar tracts and the paramedian tegmentum. Ischemia to these structures results in quadriplegia, bulbar dysfunction (e.g., facial weakness, dysarthria), and oculomotor deficits (e.g. horizontal gaze palsy).
